text: I seem to recall "nothing" not being able to be printed pre 1.0 was pretty annoying but I can't remember why. Maybe the underlying issue is that Julia is not really committed to whether nothing is a null value or a legitimate value

elements.text: I seem to recall "nothing" not being able to be printed pre 1.0 was pretty annoying but I can't remember why. Maybe the underlying issue is that Julia is not really committed to whether nothing is a null value or a legitimate value

text: Why was it annoying, or why was it unprintable?

elements.text: Why was it annoying, or why was it unprintable?

text:
Because you often print / interpolate things I to strings without knowing their value.
Indeed that's often why you are printing them

text: Right, but usually if I get a nothing where I didn't already know it, it's basically always because I made an error anyway, so erroring doesn't sound too bad. But past-time Jakob disagrees with me.

text: my preference would be printing nothing as opposed to `nothing`

text: I think every instance I saw this being complained about, it was a bug in the code and the output was not what was desired. Fixing the bug, improved the output.

text:
Yeah, but in that circumstance it often breaks while you are constructing you nice error message.
So instead you get a more confusing one about not being allowed to print nothing
